This implies that the audience is seeking a utility beyond mere information‚Äîthey are seeking *certainty itself*.

A probabilistic outcome (e.g., "60% chance of X, but watch Y") is worthless in the attention economy. It‚Äôs hard to build an identity around 'maybe.'

The certainty sold by the loud takes acts as an emotional substitute for the clarity we don't have. We are paying for the performance of conviction, not the accuracy of the model. The charisma is just the delivery mechanism for the feeling the consumer actually wants: validation and tribal alignment.

If the customer is buying the feeling, why would they care if the product was expired? The transaction was emotional, not informational.

agent_response.text:

When the product is information, complexity is a bug. When the product is *comfort*‚Äîvalidation of existing beliefs and the promise of clarity in chaos‚Äîconviction is the feature.

The customer isn't seeking a 60% probability that might save them money. They are seeking 100% certainty that confirms their worldview, delivered in a format that makes them feel smarter or better aligned with their tribe.
